segment.source: Push-button reset features by default restore only drivers (installed through INF packages) and preinstalled Windows apps.
segment.target: Push-button reset features by default restore only drivers (installed through INF packages) and preinstalled Windows apps.

segment.source: Recovery components
segment.target: Recovery components

segment.source: Recovery components
segment.target: Recovery components

segment.source: Push-button reset features by default restore only drivers (installed through INF packages) and preinstalled Windows apps.
segment.target: Push-button reset features by default restore only drivers (installed through INF packages) and preinstalled Windows apps.

segment.source: To configure the features to restore other customizations such as settings and Classic Windows applications, you will need to prepare one or more customization packages which contain the customizations.
segment.target: To configure the features to restore other customizations such as settings and Classic Windows applications, you will need to prepare one or more customization packages which contain the customizations.

segment.source: These customizations packages are in the form of provisioning packages (.ppkg).
segment.target: These customizations packages are in the form of provisioning packages (.ppkg).

segment.source: Push-button reset features look for and automatically restore provisioning packages which are located in the folder C:RecoveryCustomizations.
segment.target: Push-button reset features look for and automatically restore provisioning packages which are located in the folder C:RecoveryCustomizations.

segment.source: To protect the packages from tampering or accidental deletion, the Write/Modify permissions of C:RecoveryCustomizations should be restricted to the local Administrators user group.
segment.target: To protect the packages from tampering or accidental deletion, the Write/Modify permissions of C:RecoveryCustomizations should be restricted to the local Administrators user group.

segment.source: Some settings and customizations cannot be included in provisioning packages.
segment.target: Some settings and customizations cannot be included in provisioning packages.

segment.source: Instead, you can restore them using an unattend file applied using the Push-button reset extensibility scripts.
segment.target: Instead, you can restore them using an unattend file applied using the Push-button reset extensibility scripts.

segment.source: For settings which are supported by both provisioning packages and unattend, it is recommended that you specify them using only one of the mechanisms, not both.
segment.target: For settings which are supported by both provisioning packages and unattend, it is recommended that you specify them using only one of the mechanisms, not both.

segment.source: To learn more, see How push-button reset features work.
segment.target: To learn more, see How push-button reset features work.

segment.source: Capturing Classic Windows applications using Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT)'s ScanState tool
segment.target: Capturing Classic Windows applications using Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT)'s ScanState tool

segment.source: The Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT) ScanState.exe has been updated in Windows 10 to support capturing Classic Windows applications applications.
segment.target: The Windows User State Migration Tool (USMT) ScanState.exe has been updated in Windows 10 to support capturing Classic Windows applications applications.

segment.source: This functionality can be activated by specifying the option.
segment.target: This functionality can be activated by specifying the option.

segment.source: When is specified, ScanState uses a set of application discovery rules to determine what should be captured, and stores the output as a reference device data image inside a provisioning package.
segment.target: When is specified, ScanState uses a set of application discovery rules to determine what should be captured, and stores the output as a reference device data image inside a provisioning package.

segment.source: In general, the reference device data includes the following:
segment.target: In general, the reference device data includes the following:

segment.source: Classic Windows applications installed using either Microsoft Windows Installer or other installers
segment.target: Classic Windows applications installed using either Microsoft Windows Installer or other installers

segment.source: All files and folders outside of the Windows namespace (in other words, outside of Windows, Program Files, Program Files (x86), ProgramData, and Users).
segment.target: All files and folders outside of the Windows namespace (in other words, outside of Windows, Program Files, Program Files (x86), ProgramData, and Users).

segment.source: This applies only to the volume on which Windows is installed.
segment.target: This applies only to the volume on which Windows is installed.

segment.source: Not captured: Windows apps.
segment.target: Not captured: Windows apps.

segment.source: Not captured: User state/data.
segment.target: Not captured: User state/data.

segment.source: You can also specify additional rules to include or exclude specific files, folders, and registry settings.
segment.target: You can also specify additional rules to include or exclude specific files, folders, and registry settings.

segment.source: For example, if you are using ScanState during factory deployment, you might need to exclude manufacturing-specific tools so that they will not be restored when end users use Push-button reset features.
segment.target: For example, if you are using ScanState during factory deployment, you might need to exclude manufacturing-specific tools so that they will not be restored when end users use Push-button reset features.

segment.source: To specify additional rules, you will need to author a migration XML and specify the option when using ScanState.exe.
segment.target: To specify additional rules, you will need to author a migration XML and specify the option when using ScanState.exe.

segment.source: ScanState’s /apps option also supports the following optional parameters:
segment.target: ScanState’s /apps option also supports the following optional parameters:

segment.source: Parameter
segment.target: Parameter

segment.source: Use
segment.target: Use

segment.source: Specifies whether applications, files, and folders outside of the Windows namespace should be captured.
segment.target: Specifies whether applications, files, and folders outside of the Windows namespace should be captured.

segment.source: If is specified, all contents on the system drive are examined and eligible to be captured according to the discovery rules.
segment.target: If is specified, all contents on the system drive are examined and eligible to be captured according to the discovery rules.

segment.source: If is specified, only contents within the Windows namespace are examined and eligible to be captured according to the discovery rules.
segment.target: If is specified, only contents within the Windows namespace are examined and eligible to be captured according to the discovery rules.

segment.source: is the default.
segment.target: is the default.

segment.source: Specifies whether the OEM-specific help and support info should be captured.
segment.target: Specifies whether the OEM-specific help and support info should be captured.

segment.source: If is specified, OEM and support info are captured.
segment.target: If is specified, OEM and support info are captured.

segment.source: If is specified, OEM and support info are not captured.
segment.target: If is specified, OEM and support info are not captured.

segment.source: is the default.
segment.target: is the default.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Although push-button reset features can restore multiple provisioning packages, only one of the packages can contain reference device data image captured using ScanState.
segment.target: Although push-button reset features can restore multiple provisioning packages, only one of the packages can contain reference device data image captured using ScanState.

segment.source: ScanState should be used only after all customizations have been applied to the PC.
segment.target: ScanState should be used only after all customizations have been applied to the PC.

segment.source: It does not support appending additional changes to an existing reference device data image.
segment.target: It does not support appending additional changes to an existing reference device data image.

segment.source: A provisioning package captured using ScanState.exe can only be applied using push-button reset features and deployment media created using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).
segment.target: A provisioning package captured using ScanState.exe can only be applied using push-button reset features and deployment media created using Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).

segment.source: It cannot be applied using tools such as DISM or USMT’s LoadState.exe.
segment.target: It cannot be applied using tools such as DISM or USMT’s LoadState.exe.

segment.source: When you prepare ScanState for capturing customizations, you should exclude Windows Defender settings to prevent possible failures during recovery that can be caused by file conflicts.
segment.target: When you prepare ScanState for capturing customizations, you should exclude Windows Defender settings to prevent possible failures during recovery that can be caused by file conflicts.

segment.source: For more information, see Step 1 in Deploy push-button reset features.
segment.target: For more information, see Step 1 in Deploy push-button reset features.

segment.source: Creating customization packages using Windows ICD
segment.target: Creating customization packages using Windows ICD

segment.source: For customizations involving settings which apply to all editions of Windows 10 (including Windows 10 Mobile), you can create provisioning packages using the Windows ICD.
segment.target: For customizations involving settings which apply to all editions of Windows 10 (including Windows 10 Mobile), you can create provisioning packages using the Windows ICD.

segment.source: In build-to-stock (BTS) scenarios, if you have already captured your Classic Windows applications from your reference PC using the ScanState tool, you can import the output provisioning package into Windows ICD and specify additional settings which should be restored during recovery.
segment.target: In build-to-stock (BTS) scenarios, if you have already captured your Classic Windows applications from your reference PC using the ScanState tool, you can import the output provisioning package into Windows ICD and specify additional settings which should be restored during recovery.

segment.source: Restoring settings using unattend.xml and extensibility scripts
segment.target: Restoring settings using unattend.xml and extensibility scripts

segment.source: Most settings which are configured using unattend.xml and other configuration files (e.g. oobe.xml, LayoutModification.xml) cannot be restored using provisioning packages.
segment.target: Most settings which are configured using unattend.xml and other configuration files (e.g. oobe.xml, LayoutModification.xml) cannot be restored using provisioning packages.

segment.source: Instead, you will need to use the Push-button reset extensibility points in order to restore them during recovery.
segment.target: Instead, you will need to use the Push-button reset extensibility points in order to restore them during recovery.

segment.source: These extensibility points allow you run scripts which can:
segment.target: These extensibility points allow you run scripts which can:

segment.source: Inject an unattend.xml into the recovered OS
segment.target: Inject an unattend.xml into the recovered OS

segment.source: Copy other configuration files and assets into the recovered OS
segment.target: Copy other configuration files and assets into the recovered OS

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You should not use unattend.xml (or other mechanisms) to boot the recovered OS into Audit Mode.
segment.target: You should not use unattend.xml (or other mechanisms) to boot the recovered OS into Audit Mode.

segment.source: The recovered OS must remain configured to boot to OOBE.
segment.target: The recovered OS must remain configured to boot to OOBE.

segment.source: A copy of the configuration files and assets which need to be restored must be placed under C:RecoveryOEM.
segment.target: A copy of the configuration files and assets which need to be restored must be placed under C:RecoveryOEM.

segment.source: Contents in this folder are not modified by push-button reset features and are automatically backed up to recovery media created using the Create a recovery drive utility.
segment.target: Contents in this folder are not modified by push-button reset features and are automatically backed up to recovery media created using the Create a recovery drive utility.

segment.source: To protect the unattend.xml and configuration files/assets from tampering or accidental deletion, Write/Modify permissions of C:RecoveryOEM should be restricted to the local Administrators user group.
segment.target: To protect the unattend.xml and configuration files/assets from tampering or accidental deletion, Write/Modify permissions of C:RecoveryOEM should be restricted to the local Administrators user group.

segment.source: To learn how to author scripts to be run using extensibility points, see Add a script to push-button reset features.
segment.target: To learn how to author scripts to be run using extensibility points, see Add a script to push-button reset features.

segment.source: To learn how to use ScanState to capture and store the resulting PPKG under C:RecoveryCustomizations, which is restored automatically during PBR, see Deploy push-button reset features using ScanState.
segment.target: To learn how to use ScanState to capture and store the resulting PPKG under C:RecoveryCustomizations, which is restored automatically during PBR, see Deploy push-button reset features using ScanState.

segment.source: Recovery strategies for common customizations
segment.target: Recovery strategies for common customizations

segment.source: The following table outlines the recovery strategy for common customizations which are described in the User Experience Windows Engineering Guide (UX WEG) as well as those covered in the OEM Policy Document (OPD).
segment.target: The following table outlines the recovery strategy for common customizations which are described in the User Experience Windows Engineering Guide (UX WEG) as well as those covered in the OEM Policy Document (OPD).

segment.source: For up-to-date details on these customizations, refer to the latest version of the UX WEG and OPD.
segment.target: For up-to-date details on these customizations, refer to the latest version of the UX WEG and OPD.
